questions.question_text_1: Consider a relational schema student(roll_no, name, class). In order to change the data type of roll_no, which of the following category of SQL command is used for this purpose?

questions.question_text_1: A role Department_Lead has the privilege of select, insert and delete on all the tables of the database. A new role Employee1 is created, and the following statement is executed. grant Department_Lead to Employee1 What privileges will be inherited by Employee1?
question_texts: A role Department_Lead has the privilege of select, insert and delete on all the tables of the database. A new role Employee1 is created, and the following statement is executed. grant Department_Lead to Employee1 What privileges will be inherited by Employee1?

options.option_text: All privileges - select, insert and delete

questions.question_text_1: Consider the following statements:  Statement 1: System Buffer blocks are those blocks residing on the disk. Statement 2: Physical blocks are the blocks residing temporarily in main memory. Statement 3: Immediate modification scheme allows updates of an uncommitted transaction to be made to the buffer/disk only at the time of the transaction commit. Statement 4: Deferred modification scheme allows updates of an uncommitted transaction to be made to the buffer/disk only at the time of the transaction commit.  Which among the given statements is/are incorrect?
question_texts: Consider the following statements:  Statement 1: System Buffer blocks are those blocks residing on the disk. Statement 2: Physical blocks are the blocks residing temporarily in main memory. Statement 3: Immediate modification scheme allows updates of an uncommitted transaction to be made to the buffer/disk only at the time of the transaction commit. Statement 4: Deferred modification scheme allows updates of an uncommitted transaction to be made to the buffer/disk only at the time of the transaction commit.  Which among the given statements is/are incorrect?

What is the possible number of conflict serializable schedule of the above schedule S.

What is the possible number of conflict serializable schedule of the above schedule S.

questions.question_text_1:
Consider the given relations: instructor(ID, name, dept_name, salary)
department(dept_name, building, budget)
Identify the most optimized expression tree from the given options that find the name of instructor whose salary is greater than 70000 and department building is ’Taylor’.

Consider the given relations: instructor(ID, name, dept_name, salary)
department(dept_name, building, budget)
Identify the most optimized expression tree from the given options that find the name of instructor whose salary is greater than 70000 and department building is ’Taylor’.

questions.question_text_1: Consider the relation election(voter_id, voter_name, age, candidate_vote_for). The number of tuples in the election relation is 1024. The attribute candidate_vote_for has 7 different values and the attribute age has four different values(i.e., below 25 years, 25 to below 45, 45 to below 60 and 60 to above). Construct a bitmap index for relation election on the attribute candidate_vote_for. What is the size of the bitmap index file?
question_texts: Consider the relation election(voter_id, voter_name, age, candidate_vote_for). The number of tuples in the election relation is 1024. The attribute candidate_vote_for has 7 different values and the attribute age has four different values(i.e., below 25 years, 25 to below 45, 45 to below 60 and 60 to above). Construct a bitmap index for relation election on the attribute candidate_vote_for. What is the size of the bitmap index file?

questions.question_text_1: Consider the smartphone relation as shown below: smartphone(IMEI, brand, color, price) (Note: IMEI is the unique number of each smartphone.) Construct a B+ tree indexing of order 8 using search key as IMEI. If the size of the block is 1024 bytes. IMEI attribute is of varchar datatype and size is 64 bytes. What is the size of the tree pointer of the B+ tree?

What is the size of the tree pointer of the B+ tree?

questions.question_text_1: Consider a multilevel index with four levels L1, L2, L3, L4. L4 is the innermost level and L1 is the outermost level. The disk block size is 1024 bytes. The size of one entry in the index file is 16 bytes. The number of entries in the L4 is 224. Then, find the total number of blocks in the L2 and L3 levels in the multilevel index.
question_texts: Consider a multilevel index with four levels L1, L2, L3, L4. L4 is the innermost level and L1 is the outermost level. The disk block size is 1024 bytes. The size of one entry in the index file is 16 bytes. The number of entries in the L4 is 224. Then, find the total number of blocks in the L2 and L3 levels in the multilevel index.

questions.question_text_1: Consider the following case study:  An IITM Online Degree Project needs a database to store information about instructors (identified by ins_id, name and phone as attributes), courses (identified by cid, cname and credits as attributes), and health information (identified by health_id and checkup_date as attributes). The instructor can work in various courses and courses can have more than one instructor; each course is managed by an instructor and an instructor can manage more than one courses. A health information must be identified uniquely by health_id when the instructor is known. We are not interested in information about a health record once the instructor leaves the organization.   Choose the correct ER-Diagram based on the given information.
question_texts: Consider the following case study:  An IITM Online Degree Project needs a database to store information about instructors (identified by ins_id, name and phone as attributes), courses (identified by cid, cname and credits as attributes), and health information (identified by health_id and checkup_date as attributes). The instructor can work in various courses and courses can have more than one instructor; each course is managed by an instructor and an instructor can manage more than one courses. A health information must be identified uniquely by health_id when the instructor is known. We are not interested in information about a health record once the instructor leaves the organization.   Choose the correct ER-Diagram based on the given information.

questions.question_text_1: Consider a RAID-4 system with 5 disks which stores the following data shown in Figure 4:
questions.question_text_2:
Consider a RAID-4 system with 5 disks which stores the following data shown in Figure 4:    According to the figure, Disk-3 has crashed. Identify the correct data present in the three blocks of Disk-3. Also, assuming that the binary values represent 8 bit ASCII code, identify the correct data word present inside the RAID-4 storage system. Consider the following statements and identify the correct statements.  1. Block A: 0100, Block B: 0100, Block C: 0101 2. Block A: 1011, Block B: 1011, Block C: 1010 3. Block A: 0100, Block B: 1011, Block C: 1010 4. The word is: ’HAMMER’ 5. The word is : ’hammer’  Note:
• Assuming block size is 4 bits. • Disk-5 is the parity disk. • The ASCII value of ’A’ is 65 and ’a’ is 97.
question_texts: Consider a RAID-4 system with 5 disks which stores the following data shown in Figure 4:

Consider a RAID-4 system with 5 disks which stores the following data shown in Figure 4:    According to the figure, Disk-3 has crashed. Identify the correct data present in the three blocks of Disk-3. Also, assuming that the binary values represent 8 bit ASCII code, identify the correct data word present inside the RAID-4 storage system. Consider the following statements and identify the correct statements.  1. Block A: 0100, Block B: 0100, Block C: 0101 2. Block A: 1011, Block B: 1011, Block C: 1010 3. Block A: 0100, Block B: 1011, Block C: 1010 4. The word is: ’HAMMER’ 5. The word is : ’hammer’  Note:
• Assuming block size is 4 bits. • Disk-5 is the parity disk. • The ASCII value of ’A’ is 65 and ’a’ is 97.

question_texts: Construct a binary search tree by inserting the following values in the following order 15, 14, 20, 10, 23, 17, 16, 2, 1, 6. What is the sum of all leaf nodes of the constructed binary search tree?

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, principles, and equations** for the **Diploma Level: Database Management Systems (DBMS)** exam, along with **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships.

---

## **Core Topics & Concepts**
### **1. Functional Dependencies & Normalization**
#### **Key Concepts:**
- **Functional Dependency (FD):** `X → Y` means `Y` is functionally dependent on `X`.
- **Candidate Key:** Minimal superkey (uniquely identifies tuples).
- **Normal Forms (NF):**
  - **1NF:** Atomic values (no repeating groups).
  - **2NF:** No partial dependencies (all non-prime attributes depend on the full candidate key).
  - **3NF:** No transitive dependencies (non-prime attributes depend only on the candidate key).
  - **BCNF:** For every FD `X → A`, `X` must be a superkey.
  - **4NF:** No multi-valued dependencies (MVDs) unless the left side is a superkey.
- **Decomposition:**
  - **Lossless Join:** If `R1 ∩ R2 → R1` or `R1 ∩ R2 → R2`, the decomposition is lossless.
  - **Dependency Preservation:** All FDs in the original schema must be inferable from the decomposed relations.

#### **Key Equations/Algorithms:**
- **Closure of FDs (`F+`):** Compute all attributes determined by `X` using **Armstrong’s Axioms**:
  - Reflexivity: `X → X`.
  - Augmentation: If `X → Y`, then `XZ → YZ`.
  - Transitivity: If `X → Y` and `Y → Z`, then `X → Z`.
- **Minimal Cover:** Remove redundant FDs and extraneous attributes.
- **Candidate Key Algorithm:**
  1. Compute `F+`.
  2. Find all attributes not in the right-hand side of any FD (must be in the key).
  3. Check combinations for uniqueness.

#### **Example (Q2, Q19, Q20):**
- Given `R(A,B,C,D,E,G)` with FDs:
  ```
  {AB→C, AC→B, AD→E, B→D, BC→A, E→G}
  ```
  - **Candidate Keys:** `AB`, `AC`, `BC`.
  - **Decomposition Check:** `R1(BC)`, `R2(ABDE)`, `R3(EG)` is **lossy** unless we add `B→C`, `B→A`, `D→C`, or `D→A`.

---

### **2. SQL & Relational Algebra**
#### **Key Concepts:**
- **DDL (Data Definition Language):** `CREATE`, `ALTER`, `DROP` (e.g., changing `roll_no` datatype).
- **DML (Data Manipulation Language):** `SELECT`, `INSERT`, `UPDATE`, `DELETE`.
- **TCL (Transaction Control Language):** `COMMIT`, `ROLLBACK`.
- **DCL (Data Control Language):** `GRANT`, `REVOKE` (e.g., `GRANT Department_Lead TO Employee1`).
- **Joins:**
  - **Natural Join (`⨝`):** Matches tuples with equal attributes.
  - **Theta Join (`⨯` with condition):** Generalized join.
  - **Outer Joins:** `LEFT`, `RIGHT`, `FULL`.
- **Set Operations:** `UNION`, `INTERSECT`, `EXCEPT`.
- **Aggregations:** `GROUP BY`, `HAVING`, `COUNT`, `SUM`, `AVG`.
- **Subqueries & Nested Queries.**
- **Views:** Virtual tables defined by queries.

#### **Key SQL Snippets (Q3, Q6, Q13, Q16, Q18, Q23):**
- **Change datatype (Q3):**
  ```sql
  ALTER TABLE student ALTER COLUMN roll_no TYPE new_type;
  ```
- **Decomposition with FDs (Q6):**
  ```sql
  CREATE TABLE student_dept (
      roll_no VARCHAR(10),
      course VARCHAR(10),
      department VARCHAR(10),
      PRIMARY KEY (roll_no, course)
  );
  ```
- **Bitmap Index Size (Q10):**
  - Size = `Number of Tuples × Number of Distinct Values × 1 bit per value`.
  - For `election` (1024 tuples, 7 distinct `candidate_vote_for`):
    ```
    Size = 1024 × 7 = 7168 bits = 896 bytes.
    ```
- **RA Expression Tree (Q9):**
  - Optimized tree for:
    ```sql
    SELECT name FROM instructor
    WHERE salary > 70000 AND dept_name IN (
        SELECT dept_name FROM department WHERE building = 'Taylor'
    );
    ```
    - **Best Option:** Push selections (`σ`) down first.

---

### **3. Transaction Management & Concurrency Control**
#### **Key Concepts:**
- **ACID Properties:**
  - **Atomicity:** All or nothing.
  - **Consistency:** Preserves database constraints.
  - **Isolation:** Transactions execute independently.
  - **Durability:** Committed changes persist.
- **Schedule Types:**
  - **Serial Schedule:** Transactions execute sequentially.
  - **Serializable Schedule:** Equivalent to some serial schedule.
  - **Conflict Serializable:** Swapping non-conflicting operations preserves serializability.
  - **View Serializable:** Final state matches a serial schedule.
- **Locking Protocols:**
  - **2-Phase Locking (2PL):** Growing (acquire) and shrinking (release) phases.
  - **Strict 2PL:** All locks held until commit.
  - **Rigorous 2PL:** All locks held until commit (strict + no early releases).
  - **Deadlocks:** Detected via **wait-for graphs**.
- **Recovery Techniques:**
  - **Immediate vs. Deferred Modification:**
    - **Immediate:** Updates applied to disk during transaction.
    - **Deferred:** Updates applied at commit.
  - **Log Records:**
    - `<T, start>`, `<T, X, old, new>`, `<T, commit/abort>`.
  - **Recovery Steps:**
    - **Undo:** Reverse uncommitted transactions (backward scan).
    - **Redo:** Reapply committed transactions (forward scan).
  - **Checkpoints:** Reduce recovery time by saving state.

#### **Key Equations/Algorithms:**
- **Conflict Serializable Schedules (Q8, Q21, Q25):**
  - Count valid permutations of transactions (e.g., 3 transactions → `3! = 6` serial schedules).
- **Recovery (Q5, Q22, Q24):**
  - **Immediate Modification (Q24, Table 1):**
    - `T0` commits → **redo**.
    - `T1` not committed → **undo**.
  - **Deferred Modification (Q24, Table 2):**
    - `T2` committed → **redo** (`A = 1600`).
    - `T3` not committed → **no change** (`B = 3000`).
  - **System Failure (Q22):**
    - **Undo:** `T5` (uncommitted after checkpoint).
    - **Redo:** `T3`, `T4` (committed after checkpoint).

#### **Example (Q15):**
- **Strict 2PL:** All locks held until commit.
  - `S1` violates (releases `B` before commit).
  - `S2` follows (holds `B` until commit).

---

### **4. Indexing & Storage**
#### **Key Concepts:**
- **Index Types:**
  - **B+ Tree:**
    - Balanced tree with keys in leaves.
    - **Order `d`:** Each node has `⌈d/2⌉` to `d` keys.
    - **Search Key Size:** Determines fan-out.
  - **Bitmap Index:**
    - Bit vector for each distinct value.
    - Size = `Number of Tuples × Number of Distinct Values`.
  - **Hash Index:**
    - Hash function maps keys to buckets.
    - **Static Hashing:** Fixed buckets.
    - **Dynamic Hashing:** Extendable (e.g., Linear Hashing).
- **RAID Levels:**
  - **RAID-0:** Striping (no redundancy).
  - **RAID-1:** Mirroring (100% redundancy).
  - **RAID-4:** Dedicated parity disk.
  - **RAID-5:** Distributed parity.
  - **Recovery (Q17):**
    - **RAID-4:** Recompute lost data using XOR of other disks + parity.

#### **Key Equations:**
- **B+ Tree Pointer Size (Q11):**
  - Block size = 1024 bytes.
  - Search key (`IMEI`) = 64 bytes.
  - **Fan-out (`d`):**
    ```
    d × (64 + pointer_size) ≤ 1024
    ```
    For order 8:
    ```
    8 × (64 + pointer_size) ≤ 1024 → pointer_size = 72 bytes.
    ```
- **Multilevel Index (Q12):**
  - **Level `L4` (innermost):** 224 entries.
  - **Fan-out (`f`):** `Block Size / Entry Size = 1024 / 16 = 64`.
  - **Levels:**
    - `L3` entries = `⌈224 / 64⌉ = 4` blocks.
    - `L2` entries = `⌈4 / 64⌉ = 1` block.
    - **Total blocks in `L2` + `L3` = 1 + 4 = 5` (but options suggest 4160; likely misinterpretation).

---

### **5. ER Diagrams & Schema Design**
#### **Key Concepts:**
- **Entities & Attributes:**
  - **Weak Entity:** Dependent on another entity (e.g., `health` depends on `instructor`).
  - **Composite Attributes:** Can be divided (e.g., `name = {first, last}`).
  - **Multivalued Attributes:** Multiple values (e.g., `phone_numbers`).
- **Relationships:**
  - **Cardinality:** 1:1, 1:N, M:N.
  - **Participation:** Total (mandatory) vs. Partial (optional).
- **Constraints:**
  - **Primary Key:** Uniquely identifies entities.
  - **Foreign Key:** References another table’s primary key.

#### **Example (Q14):**
- **Correct ER Diagram:**
  - `instructor` (1:N) `manages` `courses`.
  - `instructor` (M:N) `works` `courses`.
  - `instructor` (1:1) `information` `health` (weak entity).

---

### **6. Query Optimization**
#### **Key Concepts:**
- **Heuristics:**
  - Push selections (`σ`) down.
  - Push projections (`Π`) down.
  - Replace Cartesian products with joins.
- **Cost Estimation:**
  - **Selectivity:** Fraction of tuples satisfying a condition.
  - **Join Ordering:** Choose the smallest intermediate result.
- **Equivalence Rules:**
  - **Commutativity:** `σ₁(σ₂(R)) = σ₂(σ₁(R))`.
  - **Associativity:** `(R ⨝ S) ⨝ T = R ⨝ (S ⨝ T)`.

#### **Example (Q9):**
- **Optimized Tree:**
  ```
      Π_name
       |
      ⨝
     / \
σ_building  σ_salary>70000
     |          |
  department  instructor
  ```

---

### **7. Security & Authorization**
#### **Key Concepts:**
- **Privileges:** `SELECT`, `INSERT`, `UPDATE`, `DELETE`.
- **Roles:** Group privileges (e.g., `Department_Lead`).
- **Grant/Revoke:**
  ```sql
  GRANT SELECT ON table TO user;
  REVOKE DELETE ON table FROM user;
  ```
- **SQL Injection:** Prevent via parameterized queries.

#### **Example (Q4):**
- `GRANT Department_Lead TO Employee1` → `Employee1` inherits all privileges (`SELECT`, `INSERT`, `DELETE`).

---

## **Mermaid Knowledge Graphs**
### **Graph 1: Functional Dependencies & Normalization**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Functional Dependencies] --> B[Closure F+]
    A --> C[Minimal Cover]
    B --> D[Candidate Keys]
    D --> E[1NF]
    E --> F[2NF: No Partial Dependencies]
    F --> G[3NF: No Transitive Dependencies]
    G --> H[BCNF: X→A ⇒ X is Superkey]
    H --> I[4NF: No Multi-valued Dependencies]
    D --> J[Decomposition]
    J --> K[Lossless Join]
    J --> L[Dependency Preservation]
```

### **Graph 2: Transactions & Concurrency**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Transactions] --> B[ACID Properties]
    A --> C[Schedules]
    C --> D[Serial Schedule]
    C --> E[Serializable]
    E --> F[Conflict Serializable]
    E --> G[View Serializable]
    A --> H[Locking]
    H --> I[2-Phase Locking]
    H --> J[Strict 2PL]
    H --> K[Rigorous 2PL]
    A --> L[Recovery]
    L --> M[Immediate Modification]
    L --> N[Deferred Modification]
    L --> O[Checkpoints]
    L --> P[Undo/Redo Logs]
```

### **Graph 3: Indexing & Storage**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Indexing] --> B[B+ Tree]
    A --> C[Bitmap Index]
    A --> D[Hash Index]
    B --> E[Order d]
    B --> F[Search Key Size]
    C --> G[Size = Tuples × Distinct Values]
    D --> H[Static Hashing]
    D --> I[Dynamic Hashing]
    A --> J[RAID]
    J --> K[RAID-0: Striping]
    J --> L[RAID-1: Mirroring]
    J --> M[RAID-4: Parity Disk]
    J --> N[RAID-5: Distributed Parity]
```

### **Graph 4: SQL & Relational Algebra**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[SQL] --> B[DDL]
    A --> C[DML]
    A --> D[TCL]
    A --> E[DCL]
    B --> F[CREATE/ALTER/DROP]
    C --> G[SELECT/INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE]
    D --> H[COMMIT/ROLLBACK]
    E --> I[GRANT/REVOKE]
    A --> J[Relational Algebra]
    J --> K[Selection σ]
    J --> L[Projection Π]
    J --> M[Join ⨝]
    J --> N[Union ∪]
    J --> O[Set Difference −]
```

### **Graph 5: ER Diagrams & Schema Design**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[ER Diagram] --> B[Entities]
    A --> C[Attributes]
    A --> D[Relationships]
    B --> E[Strong Entity]
    B --> F[Weak Entity]
    C --> G[Simple]
    C --> H[Composite]
    C --> I[Multivalued]
    D --> J[Cardinality 1:1, 1:N, M:N]
    D --> K[Participation Total/Partial]
    A --> L[Constraints]
    L --> M[Primary Key]
    L --> N[Foreign Key]
```
